WAR CRISIS. FRANCE’S NEUTRALITY QUESTIONED INDIGNATION IN JAPAN. BRITISH REPRESENTATIONS. FRENCH OFFICIAL DENIAL.
Tokio, May 5. A section of the Japanese Press is urging the Government to take the strongest measures in consequence of the stay of the Baltic Fleet Even responsible organs are calling for prompt and independent action. (Reuter.)
London, May 8. The "Times" reports from Tokio that the indignation in Japan is increasing. Even the soberest journals declare that France has vir- tually taken up arms against Japan and plainly state England's duty to prevent the interference of third parties.
The “Times," in a significant article, states that no more deplorable error can be com- milted by France than to suppose that the complaints of Japan will be treated lightly. While everything is done to provent the rup- ture of the “entente," France must remember that England will have no choice but to comply if the facts alleged by the Japanese are estab- lishedand Japan asks us to fulfil the obligations of the alliance. (Reuter.)
London, May 8 The Markets are weak on account of the international situation and the article in the “Times."
It is understood that Lord Lansdowne has made earnest representations to France with reference to the necessity of a strict observance of neutrality.
Reuter’s Agent learns from Tokio that the Japanese complaints are mainly directed against the provisioning and equipping of the Baltic Fleet from neutral shores. (Reuter.)
Paris, May 8. The official statement of the Government says that not only have the most positive instructions been sent to the authorities in Indo China to enforce the neutrality regula- tions, but that it has unremittingly seen to the execution of these instructions. (Reuter.
Paris, May 8. The Japanese Minister had a prolonged inter- view with M. Delcassé yesterday. (Reuter)
Paris, May 8. A note of the Havas Agency denies the allegations contained in a telegram from Hong Kong, according to which France had com- mitted a breach of the neutrality roles. (H.)
MANCHURIA. BRUSH WITH JAP CAVALRY.
St. Petersburg, May 5. General Linievitch telegraphs that the Japa- nese cavalry drove back our mounted outpost on the 4 th inst. (Reuter.)
UNKNOWN FLEET SIGHTED.
Labuan, May 8. Tho German S.S. “Chiengmai" passed on the 5th inst 70 miles to the north-east, an unknown fleet composed of two divisions. It was apparently coaling. (Reuter.)
RUSSIAN TORPEDO-BOATS RELEASED.
Lubeck, May 8. The torpedo-boats have been released, the authorities considering it will take six months to make them seaworthy. (Reuter.)
ANTI-SEMITISM AT WARSAW.
Warsaw, May 8. There is a strong anti-Semitic feeling here, in consequence of the Jewish shopkeepers and cab drivers ignoring the Socialists. The pro mine/indiscernible letter/t citizens are persuading the Governor to investigate the disturbances of the 1st inst. with a view to allaying the popular irrita- tion. (Reuter.)
FIRE IN NEWSKI SHIPBUILDING YARD.
St. Petersburg, May 8. Fourteen buildings ip Newski shipbuilding yard were destroyed by fire last night; six were also partly destroyed. (Reuter.)
FREIGHTS TO CALCUTTA REDUCED
Liverpool, May 8. Owing to the war rates of insurance the Liverpool lines have to day reduced freights for rough goods to Calcutta by 5s. per ton. (Reuter.)
AUTOMOBILE BOAT RACE.
Port Mahon, May 8. “Fiat” (Italian) was first in the antomobile boat race. (Havas.)
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Sanitary Dept.—Dr. Philippe Paraschivas has been authorised to follow his profession in Egypt.
Egyptian Estates, Limited.—It has been decided to hold a statutory meeting of the above company on June 3.
Egyptian Army.—The troops in Cairo and the cadets of the Military School paraded at Mohamed Aly-square at 8 o’clock this morning.
Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Abdeen district of Cairo during to-morrow night and dawn of Thursday will be poisoned by the police.
Mohamed Aly Centenary.— Subscriptions in Cairo for the celebration of the Mohamed Aly centenary have already reached a total of L.E. 1,056. The Ministers each subscribed L.E. 20.
Messageries Maritimes—The M. M. Com- pany reform us that as from this date the de- parture of their mail steamer for Port Said and Syria will take place on Thursday at 8 a.m. instead of noon.
Anglo-Egyptian Rank, Limited.—The di- rectors have decided to pay an interim divi- dend on June 1 of 5s. per share, being at the rate of 10 per cent, per annum for the half- year ended February 28, 1905.
Exemption from Military Service. — The amount paid by conscripts for exemption from military service during the past three months is L.E. 45,959, as compared to L.E. 44,300 duriug the same period last year.
The Plague.—Last week, five cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt, i.e., 1 at Port Said, 1 at Barchoum-ei-Soghra, 1 at Tant-el- Ghezireh, and two at Kom-el-Atroun, Toukh district, province of Kalioubieh.
Suez Canal.—12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 5th inst., 9 of which were British, 1 French, 1 German, 1 Dutch. The day’s receipts were frs. 325,584.63, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,804,846.42.
Egypt is among the twenty-two different States that up to the present time have noti- fied their adhesion to the King of Italy’s pro- posal to found an Internatioual Institute of Agriculture, and have announced that they will send delegates.
Quarantine Service.--Dr. U. Cano has been appointed physician for the disinfection service at Suez and at Moses’ Wells, in place of Dr. Zirolio, who has beeu appointed director of the bacteriological laboratory of the Qua- rantine Service, at Port Said.
Anglo-Egyptian Postal Communication will be considerably facilitated by the Simplon Tunnel. When the mail takes that route instead of the present one by way of the St. Gothard Pass, the mail between London and Egypt will arrive five hours earlier.
Improvement of Mosques.—A draft decree opening a now credit for the improvement of the internal service of the different mosques, has been submitted for the approval of H. H. the Khedive, who has agreed to it in principle and remitted it to the Wakfs Superior Council.
The Native Press.—Ahmed Abbasi and Raghib Hassan, the editors of the comic paper, “El Khalaâ,” are to be tried before the Saïda Zeynab Court on the 15th inst, for publishing some libellous articles against Ahmed Bey Talaat, the well-known native notable of Cairo.
Khedivial Club.—On the occasion of the fête in Mohamed Aly-square on Saturday next the Khedivial Club premises will be thrown open to ladies in the evening. The club veran- dah is to be beautifully illuminated on that evening and an orchestra has been engaged to play in the large reading room of the club.
White Slave-Traffic.—At the meeting of the executive bureau of the Committee for the Suppression of the White Slave Traffic, held at the Alexandria Gouvernorat yesterday after- noon, the following officials were appointed : Baron Jacques de Menasce, president; Mr. George Zervudachi, treasurer, and Mr. Kreutschner, secretary.
Bank of Athens. — The business of the Bank of Athens at Alexandria and in Egypt generally has so increased that a branch of this bank is shortly to be opened at Cairo. Mr. Jean Joannides, the manager of the Alexan dria branch, on returning from Europe, will proceed to Cairo in connection with the pro- ject. Mr. Joannides and his wife are leaving Alexandria to-morrow by the Florio-Rubattino packet for a six weeks' trip to Italy and Paris.
Exciting Scene at a Bank.—The Alex andria branch of the Credit Lyonnais was the scene of some excitement this morning. A mad Arab, who is a well-known character at Minet-el Bassal, entered the bank and went up to one of the cashiers demanding that his wages should be paid. The cashier replied that nothing was owing to him and that he was not in the employment of the bank. The mad man retaliated by drawing a double barrelled pistol and discharging the contents of both barrells at the cashier. An exciting scene ensued. The bank, as usual, was crowded with customers and the unwonted discharge of fire- arms caused considerable confusion. For- tunately the cashier was not wounded and the madman was pinioned by one of the bank’s kavasses and handed over to the custody of the police.
FAYOUM BRIGANDAGE. MAJOR ELGOOD INTERVIEWED.
(From our Correspondent).
Medinet el-Fayoum, Monday. In reference to the cases of brigandage which I dealt with in my letter of Saturday last, I decided to pay a visit to Major Elgood. Inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, to ascertain some facts connected with the oc- currence. The Major, I am sorry to say, is suffering from the sting of a fly which he got while on duty in the provinces. The consequence was that a large carbuncle formed in the back of his neck, and an opera- tion under chloroform was found necessary. When I visited him yesterday he was better and out of danger. He could not, however, leave for Cairo, as the Bishmo case was a source of great anxiety to him.
Major Elgood informed me that six of the band of desperadoes had already been placed under arrest, and that one of them had con- fessed his guilt. He has sent the Moudir to the Ghizeh province and the commandant of police to Mehatela village to arrest the remainder of the band and its leader.
I have been informed that the leader of the brigand is Abbass Ezomer, a celebrated brigand from Ghizeh province.
Much credit is due to Major Elgood and his men for their prompt discovery and arrest of the members of this terrible gang, whose depredations are well-known to the inhabitants of the three provinces.
A CAIRO BANKRUPTCY.
The tradespeople in Cairo are watching with great interest the proceedings in the case of the firm of Dick&Co, Sharia Kasr el Nil, French subjects, a commercial judg- ment having been given on 29th April last declaring this firm bankrupt. The interest is partly extrinsic, in view of the extraor- dinary proceedings which obtained in the case of the Hamilton bankruptcy, for it has been alleged that if Hamilton had not been a British subject, he would have received far different treatment. M. P. Caloyanni, who was the official receiver in the Hamilton bankruptcy, has been appointed to that posi- tion in the present case, whilst Judge Tuck, who presided in the first case, will also adjudi- cate in the instance of M. Dick&Co.
A NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.
Yesterday’s "Journal Officiel" contains the articles of association of the Société Egyp- tienne d’Enterprises Urbaine et Rurales, which has been formed with a capital of £300,000, divided into 75,000 shares of £4 each, to undertake the business of the purchase of all house property, urban or rural, the construc- tion of house property on urban lands, their rental, the improvement and exploitation of rural lands, their resale, the undertaking of works for third parties, and loans on mortgage. The share capital has been entirely subscribed as follows :— Mr. Catmiz 10,000 shares ; M. Green 8,500 shares; M. Felix B. de Menasce 18,000 shares; M. Alfred B. de Menasce 18,300 shares ; M. Enrico Nahman 11,000 shares ; M. Piha Bey 8,000 shares ; M. Sauveur Tivoli 1,000 shares.
PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION.
We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the announcement of the Port Said Salt Association’s new issue of 66,500 shares, which appears on our fourth page. The sub- scription list opens to-morrow and as soon as the shares are fully paid up,viz., after the 15th June, the bearer-warrants will be delivered without any stamp duty.
PROSPERITY IN COTTON TRADE.
In a statement issued last week by Mr. William Tattersall of Manchester it is stated that five large Lancashire cotton spinning con- cerns, which took stock on Saturday week, have declared a total profit equal to 23 per cent, per annum on share capital, after in- terest has been allowed for loans and an adequate sum for depreciation of plant. The gain is equal to 10 per cent. per annum on all capital employed, viz., £476,396.
THE ALLEGED POLICE OUTRAGE.
The member of the Alexandria City Police force, who is accused of having committed an assault in Cherif Pasha-street on the morning of H.H. the Khedive’s arrival at Alexandria, has been reduced in rank and fined, and will be tried for assault
Our local confrères appear to labour under the impression that the policeman exercised his authority on that occasion in order to keep the street clear of traffic for the Khedivial cortège. This is not the case. The policeman stopped the hand cart belonging to M. Schuler in accordance with the terms of a local by-law prohibiting the passage of hand-carts through Cherif Pasha-street. It is presumed that the Berberee servant of Mr. Schuler, who was trundling the handcart did not make it clear to the policeman that he was merely going to a shop in the street itself, and the policeman therefore naturally concluded that the man wanted to push the hand-cart through Cherif Pasha-street and consequently forbade him, -rather forcibly, it must be admitted.

THE PIGMIES AT CAIRO. PERMISSION GRANTED TO LEAVE.
The Foreign Office and Lord Cromer have withdrawn their prohibition of the landing in England of the pigmies brought by Colonel Harrison from the Ituri Forest. They will leave Cairo shortly for England.
It is the intention of Colonel Harrison to have the dwarfs conveyed to his home, at Brandesburton Hull, near Hull. They will also go to Londesborough Park, the country seat of the Earl and Countess of Londesbo- rough, and will visit London and the principal provincial towns. Colonel Harrison has promis- ed to take them back to their own country at the end of the summer. He does not anticipate any difficulty with regard to their food. They have already gained in weight.
PRINCE COLIBRI.
It is somewhat singular to hear at the same time that we receive the news that all objection is withdrawn to the sending of Colonel Harrison's pigmies to London, that the impresario of the miniature man who has been on exhibition at Cairo and Alexandria for some months has been prohibited to remove his charge from this country. The party were to have sailed on Wednesday last; all was in order, passages booked to Syria, and passports obtain- ed, when the Russian Consul intervened by direction of the Russian Ambassador in Paris, and prevented the Prince from going.
Probably the intervention is on account of the little man being of Finnish birth, but as he has been in the care of his present foster-mother for some eleven years, during which time he has freely moved about the world, probably there is some reason for the procedure which does not appear on the surface.
The intervention of the British Consul has been sought, and for the present the matter is in abeyance.
MUSIC HALL FOR ALEXANDRIA.
We are informed that a group of finan- ciers, on the initiative of Mr. George Ralli, is in course of formation for the purpose of erecting a first class music-hall on the site of the old terminus of the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway.
M. LUIGI CALISE’S CONCERT.
A grand vocal and instrumental concert was given by Professor Calise at the New Khedivial Hotel on Sunday afternoon, and was attended by a large audience which quite filled the room. The concert commenced with a Menuet du XVIII. Siecle performed on two pianofortes by four players, Miles A. Boccia, G. Dedes, B. Boccia, and G. Boccia. The performance was given with great spirit and in excellent time. A tenor solo Mallinata, by Leoncavallo, followed, sung by Mr. J. Calleja, whose powerful voice required a larger space in which to give it full effect, its musical qualities quite failing to show in this piece. Mme P. Calzetti sang the Cavatina I due Foscari by Verdi and Gioconda (Suicidio) by Ponchinelli. In both these pieces her flexible voice was heard to great advantage. She also sang the duet in the grand finale to the second act of Verdi’s Aida with Mr. J. Calleja, a long and trying performance that severely tested both of the voices, and in which that of the tenor showed to greater advantage than in his solo (for which, however, we omitted to say he received an encore). Mile G. Capozzi sang a soprano air from Cavalleria Rusticana with great effect and an air from Tosca by Puccini (Vissi d'arte). She has a sympathetic voice of great freshness. Mr. J. Guittieres Pegna sang 2da da Mattinata by Tosti and Mr. L. Bracha Tardi (mélodie) by Densa.
The instrumental part of the concert was greatly appreciated. In addition to the double pianoforte duet which opened the concert and to which we have alluded. M. A. Tempe- rino and Mlle Bonomi played two duets, for violin and pianoforte one a Sympho- nic concertante by Mozart, the other Con- oerto No. 1 op. 16 by Beriot. Both pieces were well executed and were greatly applauded. The second encore of the afternoon was gained by a brilliant pianoforte solo, Scherzo, by Chopin, executed by Mlle M. Gianny. The concert was a great and deserved success, reflecting the highest credit upon Professor Calise.

LORD CROMER’S TRIP. RETURN TO CAIRO.
Lord and Lady Cromer arrived at Zagazig at 11 a.m. yesterday on a steamer belonging to the Irrigation Department. The Moudir and Mr. Felice, H.B.M.’s Vice-Consul, at once went on board to pay their respects. In the after noon Lord and Lady Cromer landed and visited the town and at 3 p.m. called on Mr. Felice and afterwards on the Moudir.At 4 p.m. a reception of the omdehs and notables was held in the Irrigation Department’s building. Tea was taken in Mr. Langley's apartment and the Moudir and Mr. Felice had the honour of partaking of tea in company with Lord and Lady Cromer.
Lord Cromer showed great interest in local questions and made close enquiries about the condition of the people, crops, irrigation, etc. Lady Cromer received the Superior and English Sister of the African Mission School. Lord and Lady Cromer left Zagazig at 4.80 p.m. for Cairo by canal. They are expected to arrive at the Barrage to-day.

CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE COUR D’APPEL MIXTE
L’Affaire Stagni-Salinas
(Arret du S mai. — Suite et fin)
Il est nécessaire de distinguer (Allig. Les bourses de valeurs) entre les bourses oh les in- térêts des valeurs sont cotés en dedans et celles où ils sont comptés en dehors ou à part.
Dans lea premières (Paris, Londres, Rome, Genève, Lisbonne, Milan, Gênes, Alexan- drie etc.) les intérêts courus sont compris dans les cours. Ainsi la personne qui schète comp- tant des titres de rente française 3% au début de Mars, c.a.d. un mois avant l’échéance du coupon trimestriel d’Avril, n’a pas, en plus du prix payé, à rembourser l’intérêt couru en janvier et en février. Il en a été tenu compte dans la fixation des cours. On peut conclure que toutes choses égales d’ailleurs et toute autre influence cessant de s’exercer sur la fixation des cours, le prix d’une valeur, au moment de l’échéance, devra être supérieur du montant du coupon, au cours de cette valeur au lendemain de l’é- chéance précédente.
Dans les bourses germaniques, aux usages desquelles Stagni figli voudraient soumettre l’opération dont s’agit, les explications précé- dentes ne a’appliquent point. A Berlin, les in- térêts sont calculés en dehors, e’est-a-dire que la valour du coupon courant n'entre pas dans la fixation du cours. L'acheteur en rembourse, à part, la valeur qu’il atteint au jour de la livraison.
Attendu cependant qu'il s’agit d’une vente de titres d’une société Egyptienne dont le siège est au Caire, d’une affaire traitée en Egypte, puer i tatremise d’un courtier de ls place d’Alex- andrie, paiement en Egypte, livraison en Egypte de titres régulièrement cotés en Egypte (quoi- qu’en pu?sent dire Stagni figli) comme il est établi psr les 17 bulletins hebdomadaires de /?/iation des courtiers on valeurs d'Alex- ndrie, produits par les parties ;
Que dans ces conditions on ne saurait ad- mettre que, par le seul fait que l’émission des obligations Kéneh-Assouan a été faite à Berlin, et parce que les titres vendus se trouvaient à Berlin, l’opération dont s'agit dût être sou- mise aux usages et aux règles de la Bourse de Berlin, sans une déclaration formelle de la part des vendeurs;
Que d’ailleurs ces titres sont vendus à la Bourse d‘Alexandrie d’après les usages, cou- pons compris. Il résulte d’une lettre du Prési- dent de l’association des courtiers que le 23 novembre 1902 il a été vendu £ 1000 obliga- tions Kéneh à 95 3/4 coup. n° 17 attaché, jouissance ler juillet 1902 ; et d’une déclara- tion de l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, qu’à la date du 25 novembre 1903, la même Banque a vendu, par l’entremise de la maison de courtage Reid & Barnard des obligations Kéneh à 95 3/4, coupon du ler janvier attaché.
Que l’on s'expliquerait encore l'insistance de la part de Stagni figli d’invoquer les usages et les règles de Berlin, si l’on prouvait en même temps que le prix convenu de 97 % repré sentait le cours à Berlin au moment de l’opéra- tion et que c’était, par conséquent, ce cours qui aurait déterminé les parties à fixer leur prix; mais que tel n’est pas le cas, puisqu’il résulte de la seu e production faite par Stagni figli, relativement aux cours de Berlin, que les oblige- ions Kéneh-Assouan n’ont pas été cotées du tout à Berlin pendant tout le mois de juin 1903, et qu’elles ont atteint le cours de 96 au 9 juillet, cours qui pourrait s’expliquer peut- être par la vente Stagni, laquelle comprenait a moitié environ de toute l’émission, qui était ainsi enlevée à la place de Berlin.
Qu’il n’est pas établi que les titres en ques- tion aient jamais attaint, à Berlin, le cours de 97 ex.
Que si, par conséquent, le prix de 97 était indépendant de tout cours coté à Berlin, "et ne répondait à aucun cours de Bourse, mais était exigé par Stagni figli d’après des consi- dérations personnelles et des exigences pro- pres", comme ils allèguent, les usages de Berlin n’avaient que fairs dans la décision de l’affaire, et la nécessité de s’expliquer sur le coupon s'imposait davantage, alors surtout que la cote de la place d’Alexandrie n’était que de 95, d'après le bulletin hebdomadaire de l'as- sociation des courtiers du 26 join 1903, soit de 4 jours avant l’opération.
Attendu que Stagni figli soutiennent qu’en tous cas les tratelli Salinas savaient qu'ils ne voulaient pas vendre au-dessous de 97 ex, puisqn’à deux reprises ils s’étaient chargés de la vente de ces titres, et que le fait bien signi- ficatif qu’à toute époque de l’année le prix était toujours le même de 97, démontrerait clairement que le coupon était toujours exclu;
Qu’il est à remarquer que des pourparlers avaient eu lieu en novembre 1902, alors que l’échéance du coupon approchait et que le prix à Alexandrie était de 95 3/4 et à Berlin de 94,90 ce qui résulte d’une lettre en date du 21 novembre 1902 de Robert Warshauer & Cie, banquiers à Berlin, qui ont fait partie du syndicat du chemin de fer Kéneh-Assouan, lesquels expliquent que ces obligations étaient traitées à 94 et qu'elles avaient atteint le cours de 94,90 à cause d'un petit achat, mais que ces cours s’entendaient pour das titres livrables à Berlin, et munis du timbre alle- mand; que dans ces conditions il est difficile d'admettre que le prix de 97 fut ex-coupon. que l’autre tentative de vente avait eu lieu en été 1901, expression assez vague, qui permet de supposer que l’on traitait avant l’échéance du coupon du ler juillet 1901; qu’en tous cas on ignore les cours avant et après le détache- ment du coupon.
Attendu, d’autre part, que, quand mâme Stagni figli auraient déclaré à Salinas qu'ils ne voulaient pas vendre au-dessons du prix de revient — 96 8/4 — il aurait fallu que Salinas aient eu aussi connaissance de la data d’acqni- sition dee titres, des conditions établies quans au coupon et au taux d’émission, et /?/
